conclusion: To determine the velocity v of the conductor rod MN when it is moving at a constant speed, we need to consider the forces acting on the rod and the induced electromotive force (EMF) due to the motion in the magnetic field.
Gravitational Force (Fg): Acts downward and is given by Fg = mg.
Magnetic Force (FB): Acts upward and is due to the interaction of the current in the rod with the magnetic field.
The rod MN moves with velocity v in a magnetic field B, inducing an EMF (ℰ) given by ℰ = B l v.
The resistance of the rod MN is R = r l (since resistance per unit length is r).

premise: ℰ = B l v and R = r l
conclusion: The current I induced in the rod is I = ℰ/R = B l v / r l = B v / r.
The magnetic force FB on the rod is FB = I l B = (B v / r) l B = B^2 l^2 v / r.

premise: mg = FB and FB = B^2 l^2 v / r
conclusion: At constant speed, the net force on the rod is zero. Therefore, mg = B^2 l^2 v / r.
Rearrange the equation to solve for v: v = mgr / B^2 l^2.
The velocity v of the conductor rod MN when it is moving at a constant speed is v = mgr / B^2 l^2.
